articles.headline: The Power Plants That May Save a Park, and Aid a Country
articles.snippet: Near Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, hydroelectric power plants provide electricity that could guard against deforestation and revitalize the war-torn country.
articles.abstract: Near Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, hydroelectric power plants provide electricity that could guard against deforestation and revitalize the war-torn country.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIRUNGA NATIONAL PARK, Democratic Republic of Congo — On the verdant savanna of Virunga National Park, a herd of elephants clustered near an umbrella-shaped acacia tree to seek shelter from the blazing morning sun. From a Cessna far above, the giant animals looked like brown-gray miniatures.

articles.headline: Houston Loves Big Business. How Much Should Big Business Now Love It Back?
articles.snippet: With the major devastation in the area, it seems worth reminding companies about how generous local taxpayers have been in recent years.
articles.abstract: With the major devastation in the area, it seems worth reminding companies about how generous local taxpayers have been in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before the damage from Hurricane Harvey is tallied, big corporations are breaking out their checkbooks.

articles.headline: Clinging to Her Drowning ‘Mama,’ a Little Girl Survives the Raging Flood
articles.snippet: With the death toll of Hurricane Harvey climbing to 38, those who survived the storm are just now learning the names of those who did not.
articles.abstract: With the death toll of Hurricane Harvey climbing to 38, those who survived the storm are just now learning the names of those who did not.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Shivering from hypothermia, little Jordyn Grace was clutching her mother’s unresponsive body as the floodwaters rose around her. A rescue team in a Zodiac boat, on the lookout for those in distress in Beaumont, Tex., spotted the small pink backpack the girl was wearing and pulled her and her mother aboard.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: A Storm Forces Houston, the Limitless City, to Consider Its Limits
articles.snippet: As it reels from the impact of Hurricane Harvey, a muscular metropolitan area that embraced growth now wonders whether growth made its flooding woes worse.
articles.abstract: As it reels from the impact of Hurricane Harvey, a muscular metropolitan area that embraced growth now wonders whether growth made its flooding woes worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Not long after a pair of New York real estate speculators founded this city on the banks of a torpid bayou in the 1830s, every home and every business flooded. Though settlers tried draining their humid, swampy, sweltering surroundings, the inundations came again and again, with 16 major floods in the city’s first century.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: As Houston Looks to Recover, Small Towns Now Bear the Brunt
articles.snippet: Houston has begun assessing the damage of Harvey, but the storm marched on to conquer a new swath speckled with small towns and home to millions.
articles.abstract: Houston has begun assessing the damage of Harvey, but the storm marched on to conquer a new swath speckled with small towns and home to millions.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Tex. — For the streets of Newton, a small town on the Texas side of the Louisiana state line, to become impassable, “the flood would have to be biblical,” Kristen Rogers was told when she peeked into the sheriff’s office looking for guidance.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Rick Rojas and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Diana’s Legacy: A Reshaped Monarchy, a More Emotional U.K.
articles.snippet: Twenty years after her death, Diana’s influence can still be felt in unexpected ways in Britain.
articles.abstract: Twenty years after her death, Diana’s influence can still be felt in unexpected ways in Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, 20 years ago, London felt like a city on the verge of a revolution. Suddenly everything was up for grabs, even the monarchy itself. For a few crazy weeks, this most enduring of institutions looked as if it might actually implode under the weight of so much emotion.

articles.headline: France Unveils Contentious Labor Overhaul in Big Test for Macron
articles.snippet: Loosening workplace regulations was a major campaign promise, but the measures could result short-term in more employees being fired.
articles.abstract: Loosening workplace regulations was a major campaign promise, but the measures could result short-term in more employees being fired.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — After 30 years of fraught attempts to make France’s labor market more flexible, the government announced sweeping changes on Thursday with the potential to radically shift the balance of power from workers to employers.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Review Finds 1.4 Million More Suspect Accounts
articles.snippet: The bank’s review of potentially fraudulent accounts also found a new problem: customers who were signed up for its online bill payment service without their knowledge.
articles.abstract: The bank’s review of potentially fraudulent accounts also found a new problem: customers who were signed up for its online bill payment service without their knowledge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after Wells Fargo’s fraudulent account scandal burst into public view, the bank said it had turned up more than a million additional accounts that customers may not have authorized.

articles.headline: For Tax Reform Lessons, Congress Needn’t Look Far
articles.snippet: The District of Columbia may seem an unlikely locale for an overhaul that has won praise across party lines, but its success offers a model.
articles.abstract: The District of Columbia may seem an unlikely locale for an overhaul that has won praise across party lines, but its success offers a model.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump made his pitch for tax reform this week, but the odds are not favorable for legislation that would reduce individual and corporate rates and promote economic growth without driving up the national deficit.
